–°—Ç–∞—Ç—å—è 30. –ü–æ—Ä—è–¥–æ–∫ –æ–±–∂–∞: Article 30. The procedure for appealing an administrative decision
1. –ó–∞–∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–µ –ª–∏: 1. The interested person has the right to appeal the administrative decision in an administrative (extrajudicial) manner.
2. –ê–¥–º–∏–Ω–∏—Å—Ç—Ä–∞—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–∞—è –∂–∞: 2. The administrative complaint is sent to the state body, other organization that are higher in relation to the authorized body that has adopted an administrative decision, or to the state body, other organization, to which, in accordance with legislative acts and decrees of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Belarus, the consideration of such complaints (hereinafter referred to as the body considering the complaint).
3. –û–±–∂–∞–ª–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∞–¥–º–∏–Ω–∏—Å: 3. The appeal of an administrative decision in court is carried out after appealing such a decision in an administrative (extrajudicial) manner, unless otherwise provided by legislative acts.
–í —Å–ª—É—á–∞–µ –æ—Ç—Å—É—Ç—Å—Ç–≤–∏—è –æ—: In the absence of the body considering the complaint, the administrative decision of the authorized body may be appealed directly to the court.
–û–±–∂–∞–ª–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∞–¥–º–∏–Ω–∏—Å—Ç—: The appeal of an administrative decision in court is carried out in accordance with the civil procedural or economic procedural legislation.
–°—Ç–∞—Ç—å—è 31. –°—Ä–æ–∫ –ø–æ–¥–∞—á–∏ –: Article 31. The deadline for filing an administrative complaint
1. –ê–¥–º–∏–Ω–∏—Å—Ç—Ä–∞—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–∞—è –∂–∞: 1. An administrative complaint may be filed to the body considering the complaint within one year from the date of adoption of the appealed administrative decision.
2. –û—Ä–≥–∞–Ω, —Ä–∞—Å—Å–º–∞—Ç—Ä–∏–≤–∞—é—: 2. The body considering the complaint is entitled to restore the deadline for filing an administrative complaint in case of passing such a period for a good reason (serious illness, long -term business trip, etc.).

–ù–∞ —Ç–µ—Ä—Ä–∏—Ç–æ—Ä–∏–∏ –†–µ—Å–ø—É–±–ª: In the territory of the Republic of Belarus, ticks of the genus Ixodes are widespread, which are carriers of pathogens up to nine infectious diseases. Of these, Lime's disease (lime - borreliosis) and tick -borne encephalitis is most often recorded.
–í –í–∏—Ç–µ–±—Å–∫–æ–π –æ–±–ª–∞—Å—Ç–∏ –∫–: In the Vitebsk region, ticks live everywhere. With an increase in air temperature above +5 degrees, they begin to activate, showing activity before the onset of cold weather. Favorite places of habitat of ticks are deciduous and mixed forests with thick grass and undergrowth. The largest number of ticks is concentrated on the grass along the roadsides of forest paths, paths. They crawl into vegetation from 1 to 1.5 meters from the Earth and take an active expectation pose for an attack on a person passing nearby or animal. The tick is able to smell a person at a distance of up to 10 meters. The maximum activity of the ticks falls on the period before the day of daytime heat - until 12:00 and in the evening, after the decline in the heat until dusk - after 18:00.
–í –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ–¥–Ω–∏–µ –≥–æ–¥—ã –Ω–∞–ø–∞–: In recent years, tick attacks have become more often registered in forest parking zones, in cities, in settlements of rural areas, in the territory of summer cottages.
–¢–µ–ª–æ —É –∫–ª–µ—â–∞ –ø–ª–æ—Å–∫–æ–µ. –: The body of the tick is flat. At the front end of the body there is a proboscis, which it pierces the skin and is attached. The tick is usually not painful and passes almost imperceptibly for a person. The ticks before sucking long enough (on average 30 minutes, sometimes up to 2 hours) choose a suitable place. Favorite places of suction of ticks - head, neck, axillary cavities, chest, inguinal folds.

In addition, it protects millions of people from severe suffering associated with exhausting diseases and lifelong disability. The advantages of immunization are increasingly applying to adolescents and adults due to ensuring protection against diseases that pose a threat to life, such as flu, meningitis, cervical cancer that can develop in adulthood. Vaccines can not only save, but also transform people's lives, providing children with opportunities for healthy development, visiting schools and improving their life prospects. In recent years that have fallen for the period of pandemia, progress in the field of immunization has slowed down. Although in 2022, 4 million children were vaccinated in the world than in 2021, 20 million children did not receive one or more doses of the vaccine. Among the factors that prevent the coverage of these woodThe vaccination include increasing conflicts, economic decline and an increase in indecision in relation to vaccines. As a result of this, sudden outbreaks of diphtheria and measles occur in the world - diseases that we still have almost completely coped with. In the Republic of Belarus, the number of cases of infections controlled and warned by means of specific prevention continues to decline or remain stably low in most positions. In 2023, cases of diphtheria, the carriage of toxigenic strains of the pathogen, tetanus, rubella, and congenital rubella were not recorded. It is ensured by maintaining the status of a country free from poliomyelitis, the status of elimination of rubella and the status of Elimation of Corey.

–ü—Ä–∏ —Å—Ç–∞–±–∏–ª—å–Ω–æ–º –∏ –≤—ã—Å–æ–: With a stable and high level of vaccination coverage, the incidence rates are reduced, and diseases can even be completely eliminated. Natural smallpox, from which 5 million people around the world died annually. The last case of the smallpox was registered on October 25 in 1977 in Somalia, and in 1980, at the XXXIII session of the WHO Assembly, it was officially announced the liquidation of natural smallpox around the world. And today, almost everyone has forgotten about this disease. In the XIX century and the first half of the twentieth century, the epidemic of poliomyelitis raged in Europe and the USA. For 1916 alone, 27 thousand people infected polio in the United States. After the widespread use of a polio vaccine in many industrialized countries, the incidence decreased sharply. In 2002, the SHO proclaimed the European region free of polio, and the task of complete elimination of poliomyelitis around the world is currently close to achievement.
4. –ò–º–º—É–Ω–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏—è —è–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç—Å: 4. Immunization is an effective measure in terms of costs.
–ò–º–º—É–Ω–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏—è, –Ω–µ—Å–æ–º–Ω–µ–Ω: Immunization is undoubtedly one of the most effective and economically appropriate measures of medical intervention that currently exist. It is one of the few measures requiring small costs, but ensuring the receipt of tangible positive results for the health and well -being of the entire population. An annually immunization saves millions of lives, preventing deaths and disability associated with infectious diseases. In recent years, the financial burden associated with incidence has significantly decreased in most member states. Each US dollar, spent on a vaccine against measles-reducules, saves more than 21 US dollars as direct costs for medical care. According to estimates, carried out during the analysis of costs associated with the flash of measles in Western Europe in 2002-2003, direct costs amounted to 9.9-12.4 million euros, which is equal to the amount necessary for vaccination of 1,358,100 children with two doses of vaccine at the levelE 95%coverage. According to economists, $ 1, spent on vaccination against rubella, accounts for $ 7.7, which would have to be spent on combating the disease itself. The costs of a child with congenital rubella syndrome during his life on average amount to more than 200 thousand US dollars. This amount includes the costs of maintaining children with severe pathologies (congenital deafness, cataracts, mental inferiority, physical ugliness), as well as to teach children and adolescents with visual impairments and hearing. Since immunization contributes to the prevention of diseases, it provides a significant, although not amenable to assessment, saving funds in relation to labor productivity, disability and access to education, as well as a decrease in the cost of treatment of diseases that can be prevented.

–ö–æ—Ä—å ‚Äì —ç—Ç–æ –≤—ã—Å–æ–∫–æ–∑–∞—Ä–∞: Curity is a highly visible disease that causes a virus that spreads through cough and sneezing with close or direct contact with infected discharge from the nasopharynx of the patient. The sick can be distributed by the virus, starting from the fourth day before the appearance of the rash and within four days from the date of its appearance. Signs and symptoms: the early signs include: high temperature, runny nose, cough, inflamed eyes, lacrimation, small white spots that develop at the primary stage on the inside of the cheeks. After a few days, a rash appears usually on the face and upper part of the neck. The rash spreads, reaching the arms and legs, holds for five to six days, then dries. Serious complications of this infection are: ‚Ä¢ blindness, ‚Ä¢ encephalitis, ‚Ä¢ acute diarrhea and subsequent dehydration, ‚Ä¢ pneumonia. In most severe cases, measles can lead to death.
–ö—Ä–∞—Å–Ω—É—Ö–∞ ‚Äì —ç—Ç–æ –≤–∏—Ä—É—Å–Ω: Rubber is a viral disease that is transmitted when contacting the sick by coughing and sneezing. The disease is especially contagious during the period of the presence of a rash, but can be transmitted within 7 days until the rash appears. Persons in the absence of symptoms can still spread rubella. Signs and symptoms: rubella can begin with mild fever within 1-2 days, soreness and an increase in lymph nodes usually from the back of the neck and behind the ears. Next, a rash appears on the face, which spreads below. However, some people in rubella have no symptoms. In children, rubella usually takes place in mild form, although in rare cases serious problems may occur. This includes meningitis and bleeding. Rubber is especially dangerous for the fetus: congenital rubella syndrome can cause a miscarriage or congenital development defects (deafness, a lag in the mental development and development of organs such as the heart).
–≠–ø–∏–¥–µ–º–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–π –ø–∞—Ä–æ—Ç–∏—: Epidemic mumps (pig) is transmitted by airborne droplets (with coughing or sneezing sick). The virus can also be transmitted through saliva. Mumps can spread until clinical symptoms appear and within five days after. Signs and symptoms: conventional mumps symptoms include: temperature, loss of appetite, fatigue, muscle pain, headache, followed by an increase in the parotid salivary gland or submandibular glands. For some, the disease is asymptomatic. In most children, mumps proceeds in a mild form, but the disease can cause serious problems, such as meningitis and deafness. In rare cases, mumps can lead to death.
–ü—Ä–∏—á–∏–Ω–æ–π –ø–æ–ª–∏–æ–º–∏–µ–ª–∏—Ç–: The cause of polio is a virus that affects the nervous system. The virus enters the body through the mouth and propagates in the intestines. It is transmitted by fecal-oral route. The source of infection most often becomes food or drinking water. Contributing factors: non -compliance with personal hygiene rules, unsatisfactory sanitary conditions. The poliomyelitis virus also spreads with coughing and sneezing. Signs and symptoms: symptoms at the initial stage include: ‚Ä¢ temperature, ‚Ä¢ fatigue, ‚Ä¢ headache, ‚Ä¢ vomiting, ‚Ä¢ neck rigidity and pain in the limbs. Poliomyelitis mainly affects children, but can also lead to paralysis in adolescents and adults who do not have immunity. Poliomyelitis can cause complete paralysis within a few hours, since the disease affects the spinal and/or brain. Such paralysis can be irreversible. In case of paralysis, the immobility of the respiratory muscles may occur, which leads to death. There is no specific treatment against poliomyelitis.
–î–∏—Ñ—Ç–µ—Ä–∏—è ‚Äì –æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞—è –∏–Ω—Ñ: Dipheria is an acute infectious disease that occurs as a result of the ingress of diphtheria toxin into the body of Corynebacterium diphtheria, characterized by acute inflammation of the upper respiratory tract, mainly by oriented (approximately 90% of cases), nose. It is possible to damage the skin in places of damage, eye or genital organs. A characteristic feature of the disease is the possibility of the formation of the so -called carriage of the pathogen of diphtheria, when the symptoms are absent or minimal and practically does not cause problems to a person. The causative agent of infection from a person to a person with airborne droplets is transmitted when sneezing, cough, conversation. It is possible to transmit the pathogen by contact and household through household items and the occurrence of skin forms of diphtheria, which is more often observed in countries with hot climate. The incubation period of diphtheria lasts from 2 to 10 days. Signs and symptoms: high temperature, weakness, sore throat when swallowing. Diphtheria toxin causes imagesthe pain of painful dense films (accumulation of necrotic tissues) on the posterior wall of the throat and tonsils, making it difficult to swallow and breathing, leading to the development of the so-called diphtheria cereal, in addition, it affects the nervous, cardiovascular and excretory systems, thereby representing a danger to health and life. The only way of treating diphtheria that allows for recovery and avoid irreversible consequences up to death is the urgent administration of anti -a -air serum. Vaccination against diphtheria and even the disease does not lead to the formation of persistent lifelong immunity, over time it is fading away. Therefore, vaccination against diphtheria is carried out throughout human life.
–ò–Ω—Ñ–µ–∫—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–Ω–æ–µ –∑–∞–±–æ–ª–µ–≤–: An infectious disease caused by the toxic bacteria Clostridium tetani is not transmitted from person to person. An important feature of the pathogen is its ability to form spores that can remain viable for years. Bacteria spores are found in the environment - in the soil, on the surface of rusty instruments, in feces of animals, humans. Disputes of the pathogen of tetanus can enter the human body through damage on the skin: abrasions, scratches, wounds or animal bites, with burns, frostbite, through the umbilical wound in newborns. The incubation period of tetanus lasts from 3 to 21 days after infection (on average, 14 days). Signs and symptoms: the disease begins with general weakness, irritability, headaches, pulling pain around the wound, and rigidity of the occipital muscles. The first and most common symptom is the tonic voltage (trism) of the chewing muscles with difficulty opening the mouth. Following Trism, other signs of tetanus appear,forming a classic triad: ‚Äúsardonic smile‚Äù due to spasm of facial muscles and dysphyachia (dysfunction) as a result of contraction of the muscles of the pharynx. The defeat of the muscles is descending type. Subsequently, convulsions cover all the muscles of the body, from which the patient is bending with an arc. With a tetanus disease, emergency medical care is required in hospital healthcare organizations. From 1 to 8 people from 10 tetanus, they die from the respiratory arrest, and in the case of recovery, speech and memory impairment remain for a long time. After the disease, the immunity against tetanus is unbiased and short, repeated infection is possible. There is only one method of specific tetanus prevention - vaccination with tetanus anxin.

–ì–µ–º–æ—Ñ–∏–ª—å–Ω–∞—è –∏–Ω—Ñ–µ–∫—Ü–∏—è: The hemophilic type B is caused by the Haemophilus influenzae bacteria. When bacteria enters the lungs or in the blood, a person gets sick. The disease spreads with the cough and sneezing of the sick. Signs and symptoms: an increase in body temperature is characteristic of all forms of the disease. The following forms of the disease are distinguished: ‚Ä¢ meningitis (inflammation of the membranes of the brain and spinal cord), ‚Ä¢ epiglottitis (edema of the umbort on the posterior wall of the pharynx), ‚Ä¢ pneumonia (inflammation of the lungs), ‚Ä¢ osteomyelitis (inflammation of bones and joints), ‚Ä¢ cellulite (inflammation of subcutaneous fiber, usually on the face). The disease can develop rapidly, and meningitis and epiglottitis can lead to death. Most children with this disease need hospitalization. The risk of death or disability is high.
–ë–∞–∫—Ç–µ—Ä–∏—è Streptococcus pneumonia: The bacterium Streptococcus pneumoniae causes pneumococcal disease. The disease spreads with airborne droplets when coughing or sneezing from a sick person or person who is the bearer of the bacterium. Signs and symptoms: there are many types of pneumococcal infection, and symptoms depend on which system of the body is affected. Pneumonia is the most common and severe form of the disease. The following features are characteristic: temperature, chills, cough, rapid or difficulty breathing, chest pain. Another serious form of the disease is the meningitis caused by pneumococcal infection, which is a damage to the shells of the brain and spinal cord. The symptoms of meningitis are: rigidity of the occipital muscles, temperature, headache and carrier in the eyes from bright light. The meningitis caused by pneumococcus leads to a long loss of working capacity or death. Pneumococcal infections are sometimes difficult to treat, especiallyfor the fact that some bacteria are resistant to antibiotic

–ì—Ä–∏–ø–ø ‚Äì —ç—Ç–æ –æ—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–µ —Ä–µ—: Influenza is an acute respiratory infectious disease, the causative agent of which is several types of flu viruses (A, B and C). The influenza viruses are transmitted mainly by airborne droplets from the sick person who is nearby, when sneezing, cough, conversation. It is possible to transmit in everyday life - infection through dishes, household items, toys. Clinical picture: in the clinical picture of the disease, symptoms of intoxication prevail. The disease begins acute at high temperature, which in the first day reaches 39-40 degrees, the appearance of headaches in the forehead, eyeballs, as well as muscles and joint pain. 2-3 days after the onset of the disease, a sore throat, cough, runny nose occurs. The fever with uncomplicated flu continues for 1-3 days, up to 5 days as much as possible. The cough can be saved for 7-10 days. Measures of non -specific prevention, this type of measures is aimed at increasing immunity, general strengthening the body, creating a favorable environmentY medium. Try not to place large accumulations of people in places without the need. Dress the weather, avoiding overheating and hypothermia. For the prevention of influenza: lead a healthy lifestyle, observe a healthy mode, including full sleep, food consumption, rich in proteins, vitamins and minerals, and physical activity. Most often walk in the fresh air: in the forest, parks. Observe the daily routine. The menu should have a sufficient amount of protein food: poultry meat, fish, dairy products. Avoid fast food and semi -finished products. ‚Ä¢ harden the body. Take the open -air bath, energetically rub with a damp towel until redness of the skin. Effectively pouring the legs - first with warm water, slowly reducing the temperature to the cold. Maintain order in the place of residence. Regular wet cleaning and ventilation is important. Procedures reduce the number of viruses in the air. Open the windows from 25 minutes to three times a day. ‚Ä¢ Moisten the airIn the room. This helps to avoid drying out the mucous membranes of the nose and oropharynx, and supports local immunity. You can use an air humidifier or close the battery with wet towels. ‚Ä¢ Observe personal hygiene. Wash your hands with soap or treat them with an antiseptic after visiting public places, do not touch your eyes, nose, mercury with dirty hands. Avoid handshakes. Clean and disinfect the surface using domestic detergents. Hand hygiene is an important measure of the prophylaxis of the spread of influenza and other viral diseases. Wash with soap will save viruses. If there is no way to wash your hands with soap, use alcohol -containing or disinfectant napkins. Cleaning and regular disinfection of surfaces (tables, door handles, chairs, gadgets, etc.) remove viruses. ‚Ä¢ Follow the distance and etiquette. Viruses are transmitted from a sick person with a healthy airborne route (when sneezing, coughing), so it is necessary to observe a distance of at least 1 meter from painnogo. ‚Ä¢ Avoid touching your hands, eyes, nose or company. The influenza virus affects the ways. ‚Ä¢ When coughing, sneezing, you should cover your mouth and wear disposable wipes, which must be thrown out after use. ‚Ä¢ Avoiding excessive trips and visiting crowded places, you can reduce the risk of the disease. ‚Ä¢ Rinse your nose with saline. This moisturizes the mucous membranes and helps to wash off the viruses in the nose. The solution can be prepared independently or bought ready in a pharmacy. ‚Ä¢ Use the mask. To avoid seasonal influenza, it is important to take measures in the complex. First of all, change your lifestyle, get useful habits to support immunity. Timely prescribed vaccination, vitamin and antiviral drugs will help to resist the infection. Why is the prevention of influenza and SARS important? Influenza continues to be the most massive infectious disease (in terms of frequency and number of cases in the world and amounts to 95% of all infectious diseases) and is one of the most actualmedical and socio-economic problems. This is an infection that causes annual epidemics and periodic pandemias, covering up to 30% of the globe population (1918, 1957-1958, 1968-1969, 1977-1978, 2009). According to the World Health Organization (WHO), 20-30% of children and 5-10% of adults are still ill with influenza, and they die from influenza from 250 thousand people. up to 500 thousand people. Acute respiratory infections are a polyetiological group of infectious diseases that are most often observed in childhood and are accompanied by additives of the upper paths. Etiological factors can be influenza, paragraphipp, adenoviruses, rhinoviruses, reooiruses, coronaviruses, enteroviruses, as well as mycoplasmas, chlamydia and the most diverse microorganisms. Clinical picture: Ori are characterized by fever, intoxication symptoms, expressed to one degree or another, and the mucous membranes of the front routes are prescribed. The danger of the disease increases with the risk of possibleMethods of treatment, which include: severe pneumonia, meningitis, myocarditis, exacerbation of chronic diseases, brain edema. The toxic effect of influenza is the strongest effect on human health. That is why pay special attention to prevention measures, the goals of which are to achieve infection, increase the body's functions and make the disease easier. Specific prevention: includes planned vaccination to prevent mass incidence. According to WHO (World Health Organization) vaccination low incidence of 90%. A vaccine is a specific prevention, which is an introduction of a virus or part of it into the body to stimulate antibodies. Immunity persists on average for 14 days. Antibodies cause the reproduction of viruses and infection. The effectiveness of vaccination for the prevention of influenza is proved by medical studies. Vaccination provides: reducing incidence of influenza, reducing complications after infectionAnd, a quick recovery and an easier course of the disease, a decrease in mortality from diseases. The vaccine can be alive or inactivated. Inactivated vaccines are vaccines that contain a large number of killed flu vaccine viruses or its industrial particles (antigens). Currently, the vaccination of the population is carried out by vaccines: ‚ÄúGrippol Plus‚Äù (for a children's population aged 6 months to 3 years), ‚ÄúVaccine for the prevention of influenza (inactivated)‚Äù (for children and adult population aged 3 years and older). , the production of the Russian Federation (inactivated vaccines contain mixed strains of the virus A (H1N1) A (H3N2) and Virus B. Vaccines are introduced in the form of injection inside the muscles. The intramuscular path is a guarantee, since it involves the best absorption of the drug and, therefore, its effectiveness. Intramuscular administration of vaccination is carried out on the shoulder (children of 18 months and older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older, older and older, older. adolescents and adults).Rippa shows that the risk of getting an influenza among unvaccinated persons is 4 times higher compared to private individuals, the incidence of vaccinated persons by 74% was lower than the incidence of unvaccinated persons. When is it impossible to carry out flu? The state of health state, when the vaccine for the prevention of influenza can be temporarily delayed (temporary deviations), or the vaccination can never be carried out at all (constant deviations). In any case, the decision on deviations is made by the doctor after examining and survey of the patient. Temporary measures for flu vaccination include an acute disease or an exacerbation of a chronic disease. After normalizing the condition (reduction in temperature and recovery) or the transition of a chronic disease to the remission stage, you can enter the vaccine. The constant vaccination against influenza is extremely rare, in the event of a sudden situation with the advent of anaphylactic shock, urticaria, and curtain swelling in the case of blond chicken eggs (t.To. Growing a vaccine virus occurs precisely on chicken embryos). Is it possible to vaccinate against influenza if there is a chronic disease? You can and should. Chronic diseases (including heart disease) are not chronic, but are manifested for flu vaccination. Patients with chronic diseases tolerate vaccination well and they have sufficient protection against diseases.

Each of the 17 targets contains a number of indicators that should be achieved for 15 years. –ó–¥–æ—Ä–æ–≤—ã–π –æ–±—Ä–∞–∑ –∂–∏–∑–Ω–∏ (: A healthy lifestyle (healthy lifestyle) is a lifestyle of an individual in order to prevent diseases and improve health.
–ó–¥–æ—Ä–æ–≤—ã–π –æ–±—Ä–∞–∑ –∂–∏–∑–Ω–∏ —: A healthy lifestyle is a prerequisite for the development of other aspects of human life, achieving his active longevity and the full fulfillment of social functions. As the saying goes: "Health is not everything, but everything without health is nothing."
–û—Å–Ω–æ–≤–Ω—ã–º–∏ —ç–ª–µ–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∞–º–∏: The main elements of a healthy lifestyle are:
–û–∫—Ä—É–∂–∞—é—â–∞—è —Å—Ä–µ–¥–∞ –±–µ–∑–æ: The environment is safe and favorable for habitat, knowledge about the influence of surrounding objects on health
–£–º–µ—Ä–µ–Ω–Ω–æ–µ –ø–∏—Ç–∞–Ω–∏–µ, —Å–æ–: Moderate nutrition, corresponding to the physiological features of a particular person, awareness of the quality of the products used
–û—Ç–∫–∞–∑ –æ—Ç –≤—Ä–µ–¥–Ω—ã—Ö –ø—Ä–∏–≤—: Refusal of bad habits: smoking, alcohol use, drug use
–ó–∞–∫–∞–ª–∏–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∏ —Ñ–∏–∑–∏—á–µ—Å: Hardening and physically active life, including special physical exercises taking into account age -related, physiological characteristics
–°–æ–±–ª—é–¥–µ–Ω–∏–µ –ø—Ä–∞–≤–∏–ª –ª–∏—á: Compliance with the rules of personal and public hygiene, ownership of first aid skills
–ù–∞ —Ñ–∏–∑–∏–æ–ª–æ–≥–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–µ —Å–æ: His psycho -emotional state has a great influence on the physiological state of a person, therefore, the following aspects of the lifestyle are also additionally distinguished:
- —ç–º–æ—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–µ —Å–∞–º–æ—á—: - Emotional well -being: psychohygiene, the ability to cope with their own emotions
- –∏–Ω—Ç–µ–ª–ª–µ–∫—Ç—É–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–µ —Å–∞–: - intellectual health: the ability of a person to recognize and use new information for optimal actions in new circumstances
- –¥—É—Ö–æ–≤–Ω–æ–µ —Å–∞–º–æ—á—É–≤—Å—Ç–≤–: - spiritual well -being: the ability to establish really significant, constructive life goals and strive for them, optimism.
